history.content:
Hey. First of all, don't be worried about taking lower-divs right now; that's what the first two years are for anyway, hence "lower"-divs. If you're concerned about mathematical maturity, perhaps taking CS70 later would be reasonable. Think about how well you did in 1A/1B and how you generally feel about discrete math. 

Also, what is your general direction in EECS or your preferred subfield? The answer to this would suggest prioritizing either EE16B or CS70/CS61B. EE16B leads to essentially all core EE courses, while CS61B/CS70 is enough preparation for most "entry" CS upper divs. 

Most importantly, what do you prioritize most as a college student? Do you really like good grades? Do you want to work on your own projects? Have more time for extracurriculars and friends? Think about your workload balance and what you're taking now and what you've taken in the past. Also generally, how do you like to take things in terms of speed? There are some who obsess over grades and a strong foundation and some who speed through everything as quickly as possible. Think about what's best for you.

If I were you, I would take option 1, because that's how I am; I would just take the hit and learn as much as I can. For you, I feel that option 2 is the best and most balanced.

children.subject: Also, and as a follow up to your suggestion, going with option 2 next semester means i'll have to take CS70, and CS61C the semester after that. Do you think it's feasible to take these two techs together?

Hi, and thanks for the feedback. I really appreciate it. So, am not sure about which sub-field of CS I want to get into, but I am sure about pursuing CS, and not EE. Well, the plan was to take one third of my upper-divs in EE , and the other 2/3rds in CS. However, with how far behind I am, that plan is not  feasible anymore, so i’ve decided to go all in with CS. Basically, I like to make friends and engage in extra-curriculars so I was planning on taking a max of 2 techs every semester, hence the reason I’ll be taking an extra semester. However, this means that I can only take a maximum of 6 upper-divs. I’d love to take more, but doing so means I’ll have to taken 3 techs each semester and instead harm my GPA. I care a whole lot about grades, because I’d want to get a masters in EECS at some point. Having said that, do you think the number of upper-divs you take matters? Like, will I be at a disadvantage if I just take the minimum 4 that are required by the EECS department really? Also, could you elaborate on why you’d take option 1?
Thank you one again for your thoughtful response.
Also, Math 53 is a light to moderate workload class and will complement well with 61B and 70 in terms of workload.

Hello, and thanks for your thought-out response. Suppose I go with your suggestion, then that'd mean that I take CS61C, and EE16B the semester after that. Do you think it's a good idea because I heard these are two heavy project-based classes? 
If I go with option, for example (EE16B, 53, and 61B), i'd have to take CS61C + CS70 the semester after that. Is it reasonable to take these two classes together?

Thanks again! (Always good to see other International students on this campus)

You do not HAVE to take 61C the semester right after that. You can chose it delay it a further semester maybe? I don't think it'd make too much of a difference because among the popular upperdivs, only 161 and 162 need 61C.
Also EE16B just has a final project and cannot really be considered a project-based class (like 61C, which has projects every 2-3 weeks or so).
Thanks! I've decided to go with Math 53, CS70, CS61B, and R1B so I can start taking CS upperdivs as soon as possible.

@OP, glad you have settled on a schedule!  Although you mentioned you're leaning more CS than EE, if you are considering ML/AI in the future, keep EE16B on your radar. It will be useful for EE127 and CS189 -- also note that EE127 is becoming an encouraged prerequisite for CS189 with the future iterations of 189.

(BTW, also an international student here!)

I'm glad the student response asked what are your college experience priorities, and I'm happy to hear in your follow-up response that you have given those thought.  Some students want to take more techs per semester, some want to do more extra-curriculars, more projects, more time with friends.  Some can handle multiple of these aforementioned priorities without compromise, while some cannot.  Ultimately, just know what "balance" and important priorities mean to you.  It's YOUR college experience. Sure, one can compare to their peers to see different perspectives, but don't get peer-pressured into straying off of your balance.  If financial pressure is not an issue, there is no shame in taking an extra semester -- you can still take grad photos etc. with your friends in your 2nd-last semester, and in the grand scheme of your career, starting 6 months later isn't a big deal!

Thank you so much, and I really appreciate your feedback. It's always nice to hear from other International students, especially when you have to literally strive to fit-in in a new environment + navigating the rigorous curriculum. It's like having to kill two elephants with one bullet.

I was planning on taking CS189, initially, but then I got discouraged by the long list of unending prerequisites, more so EE126, and EE127. I just don't see the point of taking two courses for the sake of prepping for one class, when I can instead take other more interesting courses in their place (I mean courses that immediately translate into more useful skills for industry- think 162, 161, 169). In short,  I could use the time I would spend on the prereqs for 189 doing other more impactful courses. I'd, however, want to hear why you think CS189 is that important of a class to spare 8 units (126+127) in a bid to prep for.

Financial pressure is definitely not an issue, and I don't mind taking an extra semester, just so I can have the opportunity of taking more upper-divs- maybe even 189 if I exhaust all my areas of interest. I will, however, admit that balancing extracurriculars, friends, and school is a very difficult thing to do. For example, pursuing extracurriculars + social life steals the time one would be spending on coursework (those extra credit points, maybe research, maybe mastering a course in its entirety). It's like we don't have the option of choosing one aspect of the college experience, without it leading to the detriment of the other (It's either school + friends, school + extracurriculars, or extracurriculars + friends, or even school alone in some cases). As an EECS student, do you feel like you're able to balance all these aspects of your college life? I'd like to hear more about how you, or other students have been able to achieve that.

Hi, different anon here. I am an international student too and I can understand your situation to some extent.

If I were you, I'd go with option 2 but with a change: CS70 instead of EE16B.

This is because you have noted that you'd like to be on the CS side of things and therefore, CS70 is going to be much more beneficial as that'd allow you to start taking CS upperdivs right away, while you can delay EE16B for now and take it concurrently with the CS upperdivs later on (you can even consider taking it in the summer maybe?).

With regards to your concern about the inadequate mathematical maturity, I feel that the case is a bit hyped up for CS70. You'd just need logical thinking skills and a clear thought process for CS70, the rest you can learn on the way. You'd definitely need to put in significant effort, but trust me, you'll enjoy it!
Awww, thanks. I blush. I've been giving advice for a long time to all my friends and anyone who asks. The ultimate goal is to empower others to make confident decisions on their own. :)
^ That's one of the best student answers I've seen on this piazza group regarding course advice. Very open minded and thoughtful :)

history.content:
Hello everyone,
So, am planning my schedule for next semester and here's what I have in mind:
 
option 1:  CS70, EE16B, CS61B, and R1B(Slavic r5b, which has a reputation of being easy)- So this is ideally the most difficult option I could take, but am a little scared, because I don't think I have the mathematical maturity for CS70 at this point in time. The only prereqs listed on the course catalogue for CS70 are Math 1a,b and CS61A. How bad is this schedule going to be? Also, I feel like am a little behind than most of my peers as most of them are almost done with these requirements. Basically, if am looking to catch up, this is the schedule that would work for me, so I can at least jump into upperdivs at the start of my junior year  (Am a sophomore EECS major); somehow, I fell behind because I was dealing with a lot of issues including culture shock and what not (International student btw) but am now at my best and doing well academically.

option 2:   Math 53, EE16B, CS61B, and R1B - this is a safe bet, since i'll have more time for CS70)
option 3: EE16B, CS61B, R1B, and a breadth - Easily the best option, but also one that will set me behind in my 
               EECS career here at Cal. Also not a big deal, because I plan on taking an extra semester.

 Opinions? (Please don't feel shocked that am an EECS sophomore who is still doing lower-divs. Not all of us can waltz through lower divs in two semesters)

Thanks, and good luck on finals
history.subject: COURSE ADVICE
